http://moyaproject.com/thumbnail.name: generate
http://moyaproject.com/thumbnail.doc: Generate thumbnails for an image. See [tag thumbnail]thumbnails[/tag] and [tag thumbnail]processor[/tag].

thumbnails.name: thumbnails
thumbnails.doc: A reference to the thumbnail tag

path.name: path
path.doc: Path to the image to the original image

http://moyaproject.com/thumbnail.name: processor
http://moyaproject.com/thumbnail.doc:
A thumbnail processor.

Defines how an image should be processed to produce another image. When [tag thumbnail]generate[/tag] runs,
it calls the each processor in a [tag thumbnail]thumbnails[/tag] with an image object called [c]image[/c].
The code inside the processor transforms that image. The new image is then written as the thumbnail. Here's an example:

[code xml]
<tn:thumbnails libname="sushifinder#thumbnails.products">
    <tn:processor name="small">
        <image:resize-to-fit width="80" height="80" />
    </tn:processor>
</tn:thumbnails>
[/code]

version.name: version
version.doc: A version number of the processor

name.name: name
name.doc: An identifier used in the thumbnail generation

http://moyaproject.com/thumbnail.name: thumbnails
http://moyaproject.com/thumbnail.doc:
Define a collection of thumbnail processors.

            This tag should contain one or more [tag thumbnail]processor[/tag] tags.

http://moyaproject.com/db.name: atomic
http://moyaproject.com/db.doc:
Makes the enclosed block [i]atomic[/i].

An atomic block works much like [tag db]transaction[/tag], but uses the databases SAVEPOINT feature to better handle nested atomic blocks.
http://moyaproject.com/db.synopsis: mark a block as being atomic
http://moyaproject.com/db.example:
<!--- taken from Moya Social Links -->
        <db:atomic>
            <db:get model="#Link" let:id="link" dst="link" />
            <db:get model="#Vote" let:link="link" dst="vote" />
            <db:create if="not vote"
                model="#Vote" let:link="link" let:user=".user" let:score="score" dst="vote" />
            <let link.score="link.score - vote.score" vote.score="score" />
            <let link.score="link.score + vote.score" />
        </db:atomic>

http://moyaproject.com/db.name: commit
http://moyaproject.com/db.doc:
Commit any pending transaction. This will [i]flush[/i] db operations to the database. If you have create new objects and you want to know their [i]primary key[/i] (id), you will need to commit them to the database.

Note, that if this tag is called from within a [tag db]transaction[/tag] tag, nothing will be committed until the end of the [tag db]transaction[/tag].

                let:email="email"
                let:first_name="first_name"
                let:last_name="last_name"
                let:password="password"

http://moyaproject.com/db.name: model
http://moyaproject.com/db.doc:
Defines a database [i]model[/i], which maps data stored in a database table on to Moya objects.

Models are referenced by their [i]libname[/i] in database expressions, the [c]name[/c] attribute is used when creating tables. If you convert a model instance to a string, it will return the value of the [c]repr[/c] attribute, with substitutions made with the object context.
http://moyaproject.com/db.synopsis: define a database model

name.name: name
name.doc: Name of the model (used internally by the db)

db.name: db
db.doc: Database to use (default will use the default database)

repr.name: repr
repr.doc: Text representation of a model instance (substitution will use the model as a data context)

http://moyaproject.com/db.example:
<model name="Permission" libname="Permission" xmlns="http://moyaproject.com/db"
            repr="Permission '${name}' ${description}">
            <string name="name" required="yes" null="no" blank="no" length="30" unique="yes"/>
            <text name="description" null="no" default=""/>
        </model>

http://moyaproject.com/db.doc:
A [i]one to one[/i] is a foreign key, that create a single reference to the other model.
This is reflected in the remote side which has a reference to the linked object, rather than a collection.
http://moyaproject.com/db.synopsis: create a one to one relationship

http://moyaproject.com/db.doc: Query the database. Will return a query set object that may be iterated over by default, unless [c]'collect'[/c] is specified.

src.name: src

distinct.name: distinct
distinct.doc: Make query distinct (remove duplicates from results)?

collectkey.name: collectkey
collectkey.doc: Collect key if collect is True

maxresults.name: maxresults
maxresults.doc: Maximum number of items to return

columns.name: columns
columns.doc: Columns to return, if model is not specified

http://moyaproject.com/db.example:
<!-- examples taken from Moya apps -->

        <!-- Get a month worth of posts -->
        <db:query model="#Post" dst="posts" orderby="-published_date"
            filter="#Post.published_date gte start and #Post.published_date lt start.next_month"/>

        <!-- delete a user session -->
        <db:query model="#Session" let:session_key=".request.cookies.authsession" action="delete"/>

        <!-- get promoted topics in Moya Social Links -->
        <db:query model="#Topic" filter="#Topic.promoted == yes" orderby="#Topic.title" dst="promoted_topics"/>

http://moyaproject.com/db.name: sort-map
http://moyaproject.com/db.doc:
Sort a query set in one of a number of different ways.

This is typically used to sort a table of results based on a value in the query set.
http://moyaproject.com/db.synopsis: sort a query set dynamically
http://moyaproject.com/db.example:
<db:sort-map src="characters" sort=".request.GET.sort" reverse=".request.GET.order=='desc'">
            <str dst="name">#Character.name</str>
            <str dst="species">#Character.species</str>
            <str dst="age">#Character.age</str>
        </db:sort-map>

http://moyaproject.com/db.name: sql
http://moyaproject.com/db.doc:
This tag executes raw SQL and returns a [i]results[/i] object.

Results objects have the properties [c]rowcount[/c] (number of rows matched), [c]rowkeys[/c] (list of field names), and [c]fetch[/c] (an interface to retrieve results).

You can retrieve all rows with [c]results.fetch.all[/c], or a single row at a time with [c]results.fetch.one[/c]. You can get a batch of a rows by using an integer index. For example, [c]results.fetch.10[/c] retrieves the next 10 rows.

If your query returns a scalar value, you can retrieve it with [c]results.fetch.scalar[/c].
http://moyaproject.com/db.synopsis: execute raw sql
http://moyaproject.com/db.example:
<db:sql dst="results" let:username="'John'">
            select * from auth_user where auth_user.username=:username;
        </db:sql>
        <echo obj="results.fetch.one"/>

http://moyaproject.com/db.name: transaction
http://moyaproject.com/db.doc:
Executes the enclosed block in a single transaction.

If the block executes successfully, the changes will be committed. If an exception is thrown, the changes will be rolled back.

Note that databases related exceptions in the enclosed black won't be thrown until the end of the transaction.

In the case of nested transactions (a transaction inside a transactions), only the outer-most transaction will actually commit the changes. For more granular control over transactions, the [tag db]atomic[/tag] tag is preferred.
http://moyaproject.com/db.synopsis: commit changes to the database

A [tag tables]rows[/tag] tag may contain either [tag tables]row[/tag] tags [i]or[/i] -- if the [c]src[/c] attribute is set -- [tag tables]cell[/tag] tags.

When the [c]src[/c] attribute is set, it should be a sequence of values to be iterated over (like [tag]for[/tag]). Each item in the sequence will generate a row containing the enclosed [tag tables]cell[/tag] tags.

http://moyaproject.com.name: argument
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Defines an argument to a macro.

The text of this tag should document the purpose of the argument.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: define an argument to a macro

required.name: required
required.doc: Is this argument required?

check.name: check
check.doc: A boolean expression that the attribute must satisfy

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<macro docname="average">
            <signature>
                <argument name="numbers" required="yes" check="len:numbers gt 0">
                    A list (or other sequence) of numbers
                </argument>
            </signature>
            <return value="sum:numbers / len:numbers" />
        </macro>

http://moyaproject.com.name: ask
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Ask the user a yes / no question.

[alert WARNING]This tag should only be used in an interactive context, such as a [tag]command[/tag] tag.[/alert]
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<ask dst="take_off">Would you like to take off?</ask>
        <echo if="take_off">Taking off!</echo>

http://moyaproject.com.name: attempt
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Repeat a block of code if an exception is thrown. This is useful in situations where you are creating a database object
    with a random token, and you want to repeat the code if the random token happens to exist. The [c]wait[/c] attribute can set a timespan
    to wait between attempts, which may be appropriate for connecting to servers, for example.

    If an exception occurs, after [c]times[/c] attempts, then it will be thrown normally.

    [aside]Always set [c]times[/c] to a reasonable value. Programming errors could result in Moya getting stuck in a pointless loop.[/aside]
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: repeat a block until it is successful

wait.name: wait
wait.doc: Time to wait between syncs (default doesn't wait)

times.name: times
times.doc: Maximum number of times to repeat attempt block

http://moyaproject.com.name: attribute
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Defines an attribute in a [tag]tag[/tag], [tag]data-tag[/tag] or [tag]widget[/tag].
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: define an attribute in a custom tag

required.name: required
required.doc: Required

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<datatag name="module">
            <doc>Define a top level admin module</doc>
            <signature>
                <attribute name="slug" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="title" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="description" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="content" type="elementref" required="no" />
            </signature>
        </datatag>

http://moyaproject.com.name: bbcode
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Add bbcode to content

http://moyaproject.com.name: bool
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Create a boolean (True or False value).
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<bool dst="bool"/> <!-- False -->
        <bool dst="bool">yes</bool> <!-- True -->
        <bool dst="bool">no</bool> <!-- False -->
        <bool dst="bool" value="1"/> <!--True -->
        <bool dst="bool" value="0"/> <!-- False -->

http://moyaproject.com.name: break
http://moyaproject.com.doc: This tag will [i]break[/i] a loop such as [tag]while[/tag], [tag]for[/tag]. When Moya encounters this tag, it jumps to the statement after the loop.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius', 'Aeryn']"/>
        <for src="crew" dst="character">
            <if test="character == 'Scorpius'">
                <echo>Taking off before Scorpius gets on board!</eco>
                <break>
            </if>
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </for>

http://moyaproject.com.name: breakpoint
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Stops the execute of Moya code and drops in to the debugger.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<!-- drop in to the debugger -->
        <breakpoint/>

        <for src="-100..100" dst="count">
            <!-- Conditional breakpoint with 'if' attribute -->
            <breakpoint if="count==0"/>
            <!-- This throws an exception when count is 0 -->
            <echo>${1/count}<echo>
        </for>

http://moyaproject.com.name: cache-return
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Return a value from a cache, if it exists. Otherwise, execute the enclosed block.

This tag can be used to [i]memoize[/i] a [tag]macro[/tag] or other callable. Essentially, this means that if you call the macro a second time with the same parameters, it returns the previously calculated result. For macros that are slow to execute, this can result in significant speedups.

For example, the following code calculates the [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factorial]factorial[/url] of a number:


[code xml]
<moya xmlns="http://moyaproject.com"
    xmlns:let="http://moyaproject.com/let">

    <macro docname="fact">
        <signature>
            <argument name="n"/>
        </signature>
        <cache-return key="n">
            <echo>calculating ${n}!</echo>
            <let f="1"/>
            <while test="n">
                <let f="f*n" n="n-1"/>
            </while>
            <return value="f"/>
        </cache-return>
    </macro>

    <macro docname="main">
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
    </macro>

</moya>
[/code]

If you run the above code, you will get the following output:

[code]
$ moya run cachereturn.xml
calculating 7!
5040
5040
5040
[/code]

The first time the [c]fact[/c] macro is called, Moya displays "calculating 7!" in the terminal. The second and third time, the text is [i]not[/i] displayed because the result is retrieved from the cache -- without the need to execute the code within [tag]cache-return[/tag].

local.name: local
local.doc: Should the value be cached for this tag only?

http://moyaproject.com.name: call
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Call a [link moyacode#macros]macro[/link].

lazy.name: lazy
lazy.doc: If True the result will be evaluated lazily (i.e. when next referenced)

http://moyaproject.com.name: call-element
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Call a element object.

This tag calls an element retrieved with tags such as [tag]get-element[/tag]. For a general purpose call tag, see [tag]call[/tag].

http://moyaproject.com.name: case
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Defines a case in a [tag]switch[/tag] tag.

If a [c]value[/c] attribute is given, it will be used as the comparison values, otherwise the tag text will be used.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: define a case in a switch

value.name: value
value.doc: Value to compare in a switch

http://moyaproject.com.name: catch
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Catches any [link moyacode#exceptions]exceptions[/link] from the previous block.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: catch exceptions from the previous block
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<try>
    <echo>${1/0}</echo>  <!-- will throw a math exception -->
</try>
<catch exception="math.divistion-error">
    <echo>The try block threw an exception</echo>
</catch>

<!-- A <try> block is only necessary if there are multiple statements you want to catch exceptions for -->
<echo>${1/0}<echo>
<catch exception="math.division-error">
    <echo>You can't divide by zero!</echo>
</catch>

http://moyaproject.com.name: choose
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Pick a random element from a sequence.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: choose a random value from a collection

http://moyaproject.com.name: command
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Defines a command accessible from the command line. To invoke a command enter its full app name after 'moya'. For example:

    [code]$ moya testapp#cmd.hello World
Hello, World!
    [/code]

    You can also get a list of available commands for an application, by supplying the app name followed by #. For example:

    [code]$ moya testapp#[/code]

    See [doc commands] for more information.

synopsis.name: synopsis
synopsis.doc: Command synopsis, displayed when you list commands

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<command libname="cmd.hello" sypopsis="Greet someone on the commandline">
            <signature>
                <arg name="who" help="Who you want to greet">
            </signature>
            <echo>Hello, ${who}!</echo>
        </command>

http://moyaproject.com.name: content
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Begin a [link content]content[/link] definition.

Content is a high level description of a page.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<content libname="content.crew.manifest">
            <title>Crew Manifest</title>
            <section name="content">
                <for src="crew" dst="character">
                    <moya:crew character="character"/>
                </form>
            </section>
            <section name="footer">
                <markdown>Brought to you by **Moya**.</markdown>
            </section>
        </content>

http://moyaproject.com.name: continue
http://moyaproject.com.doc: When Moya encounters this tag in a loop, such as [tag]while[/tag] or [tag]for[/tag], it ignores the remaining code in the block and [i]continues[/i] to the next item in the loop.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: skip remaining code in a loop
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius', 'Aeryn']"/>
        <for src="crew" dst="character">
            <if test="character == 'Scorpius'">
                <echo>Scorpius is not allowed on board!</eco>
                <continue/>
            </if>
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </for>

http://moyaproject.com.name: copy
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Copy a variable from one location to another

http://moyaproject.com.name: css
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
This content tag creates a [c]<style>[/c] element in html, with the enclosed text.

It is generally preferable to use [tag]include-css[/tag], but this tag can be useful to insert dynamically generated CSS.

section.name: section
section.doc: Section to add CSS tag to

http://moyaproject.com.name: data-tag
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Define a data tag. See [doc customtags].

undocumented.name: undocumented
undocumented.doc: Set to yes to disabled documentation for this tag

synopsis.name: synopsis
synopsis.doc: Short description of the data tag

http://moyaproject.com.name: datetime
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Create a Moya [i]datetime[/i] object.

Datetime objects have the following properties:

[definitions]
    [define year]The year (integer)[/define]
    [define month]The month (integer) (1 is January)[/define]
    [define day]The day (integer)[/define]
    [define hour]The hours in the time[/define]
    [define minute]The number of minutes in the time[/define]
    [define second]The number of seconds in the time[/define]
    [define microseconds]The number of microseconds in the time[/define]
    [define isoformat]The date/time in [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601]ISO 8601[/url] format[/define]
    [define next_day]The date/time + 24 hours[/define]
    [define previous_day]The date/time - 24 hours[/define]
    [define year_start]January 1st at the beginning of the year[/define]
    [define day_start]The beginning of the day (midnight)[/define]
    [define next_year]January 1st of the next year[/define]
    [define next_month]First day of the next month[/define]
    [define next_day]The start of the next day[/define]
    [define previous_day]The start of the previous day[/define]
    [define previous_year]Jan 1st of the previous year[/define]
    [define previous_monthy]First date of the previous month[/define]
    [define days_in_month]Number of days in the current month[/define]
    [define epoch]Number of seconds since Jan 1st 1970[/define]
    [define html5_datatime]Date/Time in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define html5_data]Date in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define html_time]Time in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define utc]Date/Time in UTC timezone[/define]
    [define local]DateTime in local timezone (references [c].tz[/c])[/define]
[/definitions]
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<datetime year="1974" month="7" day="5" dst="birthday" />
        <echo>Your birthday is ${localize:birthday}</echo>

http://moyaproject.com.name: debug
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Executes a block only if Moya is in debug mode. You can enable debug mode the setting 'debug' under the project section. This tag is equivalent to the following:

[code xml]
<if test=".debug">
    <echo>Moya is in debug mode. Relax.</echo>
</if>
[/code]

[alert]Be careful to not do anything inside this tag that your project may depend on. It will not execute in a production environment![/alert]

http://moyaproject.com.name: dec
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Decrement (subtract 1 from) a value.

http://moyaproject.com.name: dedent
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Removes common whitespace from the start of lines.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: remove common whitespace from a string
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<dedent dst="text">
            This text will have the initial whitespace removed
                This will start with only 4 spaces
            Back to column 0
        </dedent>

http://moyaproject.com.name: default-case
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Defines the [i]default[/i] case in a [tag]switch[/tag] tag.

http://moyaproject.com.name: default-markup
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Use default markup if a value is None or missing
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: use default markup for missing values

http://moyaproject.com.name: defer
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Defer to a given element, such as a [tag]macro[/tag]. [i]Deferring[/i] to a macro is similar to calling it, but no new [i]scope[/i] is created. This means that the macro has access to the same variables where defer was called.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<macro docname="board">
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </macro>

        <macro docname="main">
            <let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius']"/>
            <for src="crew" dst="character">
                <defer to="board"/>
            </for>
        </macro>

http://moyaproject.com.name: delete-cookie
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Delete a previously set cookie.

http://moyaproject.com.name: dict
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Create a [i]dictionary[/i] object. A dictionary maps [i]keys[/i] on to [i]values[/i]. The keys and values are defined in the enclosing block, or via the [i]let map[/i].

default.name: default
default.doc: Default object to return if the key isn't in the dict

sequence.name: sequence
sequence.doc: Optional sequence of key / value pairs to initialize the dict

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<dict dst="species">
            <str dst="Bibo">Hobbit</dst>
            <str dst="Gandalph">Wizard</dst>
        </dict>
        <!-- Alternatively -->
        <dict dst="species" let:Bilbo="Hobbit" let:Gandalph="Wizard" />
        <echo>Bilbo is a ${species['Bilbo']}</echo>

http://moyaproject.com.name: doc
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Write documentation for a widget or custom tag.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<widget name="post" template="post.html">
            <doc>Renders a single post</doc>
            <!-- widget code -->
        </widget>

http://moyaproject.com.name: done
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Exists the current callable immediately with no return value. Note, this is not equivalent to [tag]return[/tag] which returns [c]None[/c].
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: return from a macro or callable without any data

http://moyaproject.com.name: echo
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Write text to the console. This is typically used in commands or for debugging. Bear in mind that in a production environment there is no console.

header.name: header
header.doc: A list of headers for the table (if given)

obj.name: obj
obj.doc: If given, then the value of this expression will be written to the console

table.name: table
table.doc: A table to display. If given this value should be a list of lists.

http://moyaproject.com.name: elif
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Executes the enclosed block if a previous [tag]if[/tag] (or [tag]elif[/tag]) statement is false, and another condition is true.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<if test="hobbits == 0">
    <echo>There are no hobbits</echo>
</if>
<elif test="hobbits == 1">
    <echo>There is one hobbit</echo>
</elif>
<else>
    <echo>There are many hobbits</echo>
</else>

http://moyaproject.com.name: else
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Execute the enclosed block if a previous [tag]if[/tag] statement is false.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: execute a block if the previous <if> statement is false
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<if test="coffee==0">
    <echo>Get more coffee</echo>
</if>
<else>
    <echo>Have a cup of coffee</echo>
</else>

http://moyaproject.com.name: enum
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Define and [i]enumeration[/i] object. An enumeration is a collection of text identifiers with an integer value. This tag should contain [tag]value[/tag] tags that define the values.

    It is generally preferably to use an enumeration over hard-coded numbers; it makes code easier to read and maintain.

start.name: start
start.doc: Starting ID if not specified in <enumvalue>

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<enum libname="enum.jsonrpc.errors">
            <value id="1" label="not_logged_in" description="You must be logged in to do that" />
            <value label="invalid_score" description="Score must be -1, 0 or +1"/>
            <value label="unknown_link" description="Link object was not found"/>
        </enum>

http://moyaproject.com.name: exit
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Exit the current command. When Moya sees this tag it stops running the current command and returns an exit code. It will also write any enclosed text to the console.

http://moyaproject.com.name: extend
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Extend a sequence with values from another sequence.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: add values from one sequence to another

http://moyaproject.com.name: false
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Creates a boolean with a value of False.

http://moyaproject.com.name: feed
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Create a [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS]RSS[/url] Feed object.

You can add items to a feed with [tag]add-feed-item[/tag].
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<view libname="view.feed">
            <!-- create feed object -->
            <get-fq-url name="list" dst="blog_url" />
            <feed title="${.app.settings.title or 'blog'}"
                description="${.app.settings.description or 'blog feed'}"
                link="${blog_url}" dst="feed"/>

            <db:query model="#Post" dst="posts" orderby="-published_date"
                filter="#Post.published==True" maxresults="25"/>

            <!-- add items -->
            <for src="posts" dst="post">
                <get-fq-url name="showpost" let:slug="post.slug" dst="post_url"/>
                <process-markup src="post.content" type="${.app.settings.default_markup}" dst="description"/>
                <add-feed-item src="feed"
                    title="post.title" link="post_url" description="description"
                    pub_date="post.published_date"/>
            </for>

            <!-- serve feed XML -->
            <serve-xml content_type="application/rss+xml" obj="feed"/>
        </view>

http://moyaproject.com.name: filter
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Define a [i]filter[/i], which may be used in expressions.

Here's an example of a filter:

[code xml]
<filter name="repeat">
    <return-str>${str:value * count}</return-str>
</filter>
[/code]

And here is how you might use it in an expression:

[code xml]
<echo>${"beetlejuice "|repeat(count=3)}</echo>
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: filter-seq
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Filter members of a collection which don't pass a condition.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<dict dst="crew">
            <dict let:name="john" let:species="human" />
            <dict let:name="rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />
        </dict>
        <filter-seq src="items:crew dst="crew" test="species !- 'hyneria'"/>
        <!-- [{'name': 'john', 'species':'human'}, {'name':'aeryn', 'species':'peacemaker'}] -->

http://moyaproject.com.name: find-element
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Retrieve an element of a given type.

http://moyaproject.com.name: find-elements
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Retrieve information regarding elements of a given type.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: retrieve information regarding elements of a given type

http://moyaproject.com.name: fire
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Fire (broadcast) a signal. Additional data may be provided to the signal handlers, by setting values in the [i]let map[/i]. Signals may be [i]handlers[/i] with the [tag]handle[/tag] tag.

    Moya will catch and log any exceptions raised by the signal handler(s).

signal.name: signal
signal.doc: Signal name, should be in a dotted notation. Names with no dots are reserved by Moya.

sender.name: sender
sender.doc: Optional element associated with the signal.

http://moyaproject.com.name: float
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Set a float value

http://moyaproject.com.name: for
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Execute a block of code for each value in a sequence. This tag [i]iterates[/i] over a sequence, and executes the enclosed block for each value.

filter.name: filter
filter.doc: If given, then only those values which match this condition will cause the enclosed block to execute.

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<for src="['John', 'Scorpius', 'Rygel']" dst="crew_member" filter="crew_member != 'Rygel'">
            <echo>${crew_member} is on board!</echo>
        </for>

http://moyaproject.com.name: for-children
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Loop for each child of an element
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: iterate over the children of an element

http://moyaproject.com.name: forbidden
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Respond to the request with a '403 forbidden' response

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-children
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get the children of an element.

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-data
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get all data from data tags.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: get data from custom data tags

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-data-item
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get a single data item.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: get data from a single custom tag

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-element
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Retrieve information regarding an element.

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-enum
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get an enumeration object (see [tag]enum[/tag]).

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-fq-url
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get a [i]fully qualified[/i] (including domain name and scheme) named URL

base.name: base
base.doc: Base (protocol and domain) of the URL

query.name: query
query.doc: Mapping expression to use as a query string

with.name: with
with.doc: Extract URL values from this object

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-locale
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get an object containing locale information

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-tag-text
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get the XML text associated with the parent tag.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: get text from the parent tag

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-timezones
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get a list of common timezones.

http://moyaproject.com.name: get-url
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get a named URL.

with.name: with
with.doc: Extract URL values from this object

base.name: base
base.doc: Base (protocol and domain) of the URL

query.name: query
query.doc: Mapping expression to use as a query string

http://moyaproject.com.name: handle
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Handles a [i]signal[/i]. A signal is a way of broadcasting to other parts of the project that a particular event has occurred.

See [doc signals] for more information.

signal.name: signal
signal.doc: Signal name to handle. Multiple names may be specified to handle more than one signal.

sender.name: sender
sender.doc: Only handle the signal(s) if sent from this element.

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<!-- Moya fires a number of signals itself, for various system events -->
        <handle signal="sys.startup">
            <log>This code executes on startup, prior to any requests</log>
        </handle>
        <!-- Handle a custom signal -->
        <handle signal="mordor.arrived">
            <log>${hobbit} has arrived in Mordor!</log>
        </handle>

http://moyaproject.com.name: highlight
http://moyaproject.com.doc: This tag is used by the Moya debug library to syntax highlight code (turning it into HTML in the process).

http://moyaproject.com.name: html
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Sets a variable to HTML.

http://moyaproject.com.name: if
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Conditional [i]IF[/i] tag, executes the enclosing block if a condition evaluates to [i]true[/i]. If the condition evaluates to [i]false[/i], the enclosing block is skipped. May be followed by [tag]else[/tag] or [tag]elif[/tag].
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: execute block if a condition is true

http://moyaproject.com.name: if-get
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Executes the enclosing block if the current request is a GET request.

Basically a shorthand for:

[code xml]<if test=".request.method=='GET'">[/code]

May be followed by [tag]else[/tag] or [tag]elif[/tag].
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: exectute a block if this is a GET request

http://moyaproject.com.name: if-post
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Executes the enclosing block if the current request is a POST request.

Basically a shorthand for:

[code xml]<if test=".request.method=='POST'">[/code]

May be followed by [tag]else[/tag] or [tag]elif[/tag].
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: execute a block if this is a POST request
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<if-post>
    <!-- validate form -->
</if-post>
<else>
    <!-- not a post request -->
</else>

http://moyaproject.com.name: import
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Import a library. Importing reads the XML associated with a library and makes it available to be installed as an application. This tag must appear within a [tag]server[/tag] tag.

    Libraries can be installed either from a Python module, or directly from a path. For example, this installs a library from a Python module:

    [code xml]
    <import py="moya.libs.auth"/>
    [/code]

    And this installs a library from a a relative path:

    [code xml]
    <import location="./local/sushishop/" />
    [/code]

    The [c]priority[/c] attribute is used when two element have the same element reference. This is typically used to override an element in another library. For example, let's say we have the following [tag]macro[/tag] in a library called [c]sushifinder.shop[/c], which calculate tax on a shopping cart:

    [code xml]
    <macro libname="macro.get_tax">
        <!-- calculate tax for an order-->
    </macro>
    [/code]

    We could replace this by defining the following in another library:

    [code xml]
    <macro libname="sushifinder.shop#macro.get_tax">
        <!-- custom tax calculator -->
    </macro>
    [/code]

    Note the use of a full element reference (including library name) in the [c]libname[/c] attribute. This tells Moya that the macro should go in a library other than the one it was declared in. If the code above is in a library with a higher priority then it will replace the macro in the [c]sushifinder.shop[/c] library.

    The [c]templatepriority[/c] is used when there are conflicting template paths. The template from the library with the highest priority wins. This value takes precedence over the [c]priority[/c] defined in [link library#lib-section]lib.ini[/link].

location.name: location
location.doc: A path to a Moya library

http://moyaproject.com.name: inc
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Increment (add 1 to) a value.

http://moyaproject.com.name: include-css
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Add a CSS path to be included in the content. The list of paths will be added to a value called [c]include[/c] when the template is rendered. Here's an example:

[code xml]
<content libname="content.front" template="front.html">
    <include-css path="css/news.css" />
</content>
[/code]

The CSS paths can be rendered in a template as follows:

[code moyatemplate]
{% render include.css %}
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: include-js
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Like [tag]include-css[/tag], but inserts a link to a JS file.

The JS files may be inserted in to the template as follows:

[code moyatemplate]
{% render include.js %}
[/code]

This is equivalent to the following:

[code moyatemplate]
{%- for include in include.js %}
<script type="text/javascript" href="${include.path}"/>
{%- endfor %}
[/code]
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: include a JS file in content

http://moyaproject.com.name: input
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Get data from the console.

[alert WARNING]This tag should only be used in an interactive context, such as a [tag]command[/tag] tag.[/alert]
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: ask the user for information in a command

default.name: default
default.doc: Value to use if response is empty

http://moyaproject.com.name: inspect
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Get an object which contains all the elements in the project.

http://moyaproject.com.name: install
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Installs an [i]application[/i]. An application is effectively an [i]instance[/i] of a library, with its own settings and serving content from unique URL(s). An [tag]install[/tag] tag should appear within a [tag]server[/tag] tag. A library must first be [i]imported[/i] (with [tag]import[/tag]) prior to installing.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: create an application from a library

name.name: name
name.doc: Name of the application (must not contain a dot), e.g. "auth"

http://moyaproject.com.name: int
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Set an integer value.

http://moyaproject.com.name: js
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Insert Javascript content.

    Here's an example:

    [code xml]
    <!-- must be inside a content definition -->
    <js>alert("Ready for takeoff!);</js>
    [/code]

    This would render the following:

    [code moyatemplate]
    <script type="text/javascript">
        alert("Ready for takeoff!);
    </script>
    [/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: json
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Sets data from JSON (JavasSript Object Notation).

http://moyaproject.com.name: let
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Sets multiple variable from expressions.

http://moyaproject.com.name: let-str
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Like [tag]let[/tag] but sets variables as strings. Setting strings with [tag]let[/tag] can look a little clumsy because of the requirement to escape the text twice. [tag]let-str[/tag] treats attributes as strings and not expressions.

http://moyaproject.com.name: link
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Create a [i]link[/i] in the context. Similar to a symlink in the filesystem, a link creates a variable that references another value.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<str dst="foo">Hello</str>
        <link src="foo" dst="bar" />
        <str dst="bar">World</str>
        <echo>${foo}</bar> <!-- World -->
        <echo>${bar}</bar> <!-- World -->

http://moyaproject.com.name: list
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Creates a list. Any data items in the enclosed block are added to the list.

http://moyaproject.com.name: log
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Write text to the logs. Every line of text can have a [i]level[/i] which indicates how significant the message is. Log levels can be filtered, so you only see relevant messages.

    You can control which log messages are written via [c]logging.ini[/c].
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<log level="debug">This may help you track down errors</log>
        <log>Something worth knowing happened</log> <!-- default log level is "info" -->
        <log level="warning">Pay attention, this may be significant</log>
        <log level="error">Something quite alarming happened</log>
        <log level="fatal">Absolute disaster</log>

http://moyaproject.com.doc: Create a list by mapping an expression on to a sequence

filter.doc: Skip item if this expression is false

http://moyaproject.com.example:
<dict dst="crew">
            <dict let:name="john" let:species="human" />
            <dict let:name="rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />
        </dict>
        <map src="crew" dst="manifest"
            expression="sub:'${title:name$} is ${species}'" />
        <!-- ['John is human', 'Rygen is hynerian', 'Aeryn is peacekeeper'] -->

http://moyaproject.com.name: map-dict
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Create a list of dictionaries from a sequence.

filter.name: filter

<dict dst="crew">

            <dict let:name="rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />

        <map-dict src="crew" dst="crew" let:name="title:name" let:human="species == 'human'"/>
        <!-- [{'name':John, 'human':yes}, {'name':Rygel, 'human':no}, {'name':'Aeryn',  'human':no}] -->

http://moyaproject.com.name: mountpoint
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
A [i]mountpoint[/i] defines a collection of URL routes which map URLs on to moya code.

    An app will typically have at least one mountpoint with [c]name="main"[/c] (the default) which is used when the app is mounted. Moya will check each enclosed <url> in turn until it finds a route which matches the url.

    An app may contain multiple mountpoints, which can be [i]mounted[/i] separately.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: define a collection of url routes

${news}
[/code] Here's what newscontainer.html might look like. Note the use of [link templates#children]{% children %}[/link] which will render the content contained inside a node: [code moyatemplate]

The Latest News

{% children %}
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.doc: Like <dict> but creates an [i]ordered[/i] dictionary (maintains the order data was inserted)/

<dict dst="species">

            <str dst="Gandalph">Wizard</dst>
        </dict>
        <!-- Alternatively -->
        <dict dst="species" let:Bilbo="Hobbit" let:Gandalph="Wizard" />

http://moyaproject.com.name: option
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Defines an [i]option[/i] for a [tag]command[/tag]. Options may be added to the command line when a command is invoked. The following is an example of how an option is used:

    [code]$ moya testapp#cmd.optiontest --hobbit="bilbo"[/code]

    An [tag]option[/tag] tag must appear within a [tag]signature[/tag] tag.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: Add an option to a command

help.doc: Argument help text

http://moyaproject.com.example: <option name="hobbit" metavar="HOBBIT NAME" help="Your favorite hobbit" />

http://moyaproject.com.name: pop
http://moyaproject.com.doc: Remove and return a value from a dictionary.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: remove a value from a dictionary
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<dict dst="species">
            <let john="human"/>
            <let scorpius="unknown"/>
        </dict>
        <pop src="species" key="scorpius" dst="scorpius_species"/>
        <echo>${scorpius_species}</echo> <!-- "unknown" -->

http://moyaproject.com.name: progress

Like a for loop but renders an ascii progress bar in the console, which will look something like the following:

    This is useful for commands that may take some time to execute.

http://moyaproject.com.name: read-data
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Read and process a data file. The [c]path[/c] parameter may be absolute, or relative from the current application.

let's say we have a file, crew.txt in our [link library#data-section]data directory[/link], which is a text file with a list of names, one per line. For example:

[code]
Rygel
John
Scorpies
Ka D'Argo
[/code]

We can read the above file and process each line with the following:

[code xml]
<read-data format="text/plain" path="crew.txt" dst="crew" />
<for src="splitlines:crew" dst="characters">
    <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
</for>
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: return
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Used in a callable block such as a [tag]macro[/tag] or [tag]view[/tag] to return data.

If you enclose any [i]data setter[/i] tag ([tag]int[/tag], [tag]str[/tag], [tag]list[/tag] etc.) in the return block, the result will be returned. For example, the following macro will return a list of three items:

[code xml]
<macro libname="get_crew">
    <return>
        <list>
            <str>John</str>
            <str>Scorpius</str>
            <str>Rygel</str>
        </list>
    </return>
</macro>
[/code]

Alternatively, you may use the [c]value[/c] attribute to return the result of an expression. The following code is equivalent to the above:

[code xml]
<macro libname="get_crew">
    <return value="['John', 'Scorpius', 'Rygel']" />
</macro>
[/code]
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: return data from a macro or other callable

http://moyaproject.com.name: return-dict
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Shortcut to return a dictionary. For example, the following macro returns a dictionary:

[code xml]
<macro docname="get_character">
    <return>
        <dict>
            <str dst="rygel">Hynerian</str>
            <str dst="john">Human</str>
        </dict>
    </return>
</macro>
[/code]

We could shorten the above using the [tag]return-dict[/tag] as follows:

[code xml]
<macro docname="get_character">
    <return-dict>
        <str dst="rygel">Hynerian</str>
        <str dst="john">Human</str>
    </return-dict>
</macro>
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: return-false
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
A shortcut to return False.

The following two lines are equivalent:

[code xml]
<return-false/>
<return value="no" />
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: return-scope
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Return values from the current scope.

This tag is useful in macros, widgets, and other callable tags where you want to return a number of values in a dictionary.

For example, the following will return a dictionary containing two keys:

[code xml]
<return-scope values="foo, bar"/>
[/code]

This is equivalent to the following:

[code xml]
<return value="{'foo': foo, 'bar': bar}"/>
[/code]

If you *don't* specify the [c]values[/c] attribute, Moya will read the values from the enclosed text (one key per line).
The following code is equivalent to the above:

[code xml]
<return-scope>
    foo
    bar
</return-scope>
[/code]
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: return values from the current scope

http://moyaproject.com.name: return-str
http://moyaproject.com.doc: A shortcut to returning a string.

http://moyaproject.com.name: return-true
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
A shortcut to return True.

The following two lines are equivalent:

[code xml]
<return-true/>
<return value="yes" />
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: signature
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Begins a list of attributes and arguments for a [tag]tag[/tag], [tag]data-tag[/tag], [tag]macro[/tag] or [tag]command[/tag].

In the case of tags, the signature should contain [tag]attribute[/tag] tags.
Macros expect [tag]argument[/tag] tags.
For a command, the signature should contain [tag]arg[/tag] and [tag]option[/tag] tags.
http://moyaproject.com.synopsis: define the attributes / arguments to a tag / macro
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<tag name="fib">
            <doc>Calculate the fibonacci sequence</doc>
            <signature>
                <attribute name="count" type="integer" />
            </signature>
            <let fib="[0, 1]"/>
            <repeat times="count - 2">
                <append value="fib[-1] + fib[-2]" dst="fib" />
            </repeat>
            <return value="fib" />
        </tag>

http://moyaproject.com.doc: Do nothing for a period of time

http://moyaproject.com.example:

http://moyaproject.com.name: switch
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Jump to a location with in a code block, based in an input value.

This tag takes a value ([c]on[/c]) and jumps to a [tag]case[/tag] in the enclosed block that has a matching value.
If there is no matching [tag]case[/tag], then execution will move to the enclosed [tag]default-case[/tag]. If no default case exists, the entire block is skipped.

This tag is useful in situations where a chain of [tag]if[/tag] and [tag]elif[/tag] tags would otherwise be used. Here's an example:

[code xml]
<switch on="species">
    <case>human</case>
    <echo>Humans come from Earth</echo>

    <case>hynerian</case>
    <echo>Hynerians come from Hyneria</echo>

    <default-case/>
    <echo>I have no idea where ${species}s come from</echo>
</switch>
[/code]

The above code is equivalent to the following:

[code xml]
<if test="species=='human'">
    <echo>Humans come from Earth</echo>
</if>
<elif test="species=='hynerian'">
    <echo>Hynerians come from Hyneria</echo>
</elif>
<else>
    <echo>I have no idea where ${species}s come from</echo>
</else>
[/code]

The [tag]switch[/tag] version is generally clearer, especially with a large number of conditions.

If the [c]on[/c] attribute is [i]not[/i] given, then the case's [c]if[/c] attribute is checked. Here's the previous example, implemented without the [c]on[/c] attribute:

[code xml]
<switch>
    <case if="species=="'human'"/>
    <echo>Humans come from Earth</echo>

    <case if="species=="'hynerian'"/>
    <echo>Hynerians come from Hyneria</echo>

    <default-case/>
    <echo>I have no idea where ${species}s come from</echo>
</switch>
[/code]

http://moyaproject.com.name: tag
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Define a custom tag. A custom tag is in a callable tag that works like builtin logic tags. Here's an example of defining a custom tag:

[code xml]
<tag name="getstock">
    <doc>Get count of available stock</doc>
    <signature>
        <attribute name="product" />
    </signature>
    <db:get model="#Product.name == product" dst="product"/>
    <return value="product.count"/>
</tag>
[/code]

You may define a custom tag anywhere in a library. Once defined, the tag is available to any code that uses the appropriate namespace defined in [c]lib.ini[/c]. For example, if the above tag is defined in a library with an xml namespace of [c]http://moyaproject.com/sushifinder[/c], it could be invoked with the following file:

[code xml]
<moya xmlns:sushifinder="http://moyaproject.com/sushifinder">
    <macro name="main">
        <sushifinder:getstock product="tuna-roll" dst="count" />
        <echo>We have ${count} tuna rolls in stock.</echo>
    </macro>
</moya>
[/code]

Custom tags are preferred over macros when exposing functionality to other libraries.

undocumented.name: undocumented
undocumented.doc: Set to yes to disabled documentation for this tag

http://moyaproject.com.name: throw
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Throw a Moya exception. An exception consists of a name in dotted notation with an optional message.

    Custom exceptions should be named to start with the [i]long name[/i] of the library. Moya reserves exceptions with a single dot for internal use. These [i]may[/i] be thrown if appropriate.
http://moyaproject.com.example:
<try>
            <throw exception="middle.earth.cant" msg="One can't simply do that!"/>
        </try>
        <except exception="middle.earth.*" dst="error">
            <echo>Error: ${error.msg}</echo>
        </except>

http://moyaproject.com.doc: Time a block of code, and log the elapsed time. The log will display two time values; the first is the wall time, the second is [i]processor time[/i]. Processor time is more useful for profiling, as it doesn't include the time spent waiting on IO.

http://moyaproject.com.name: title
http://moyaproject.com.doc:
Set the title for content. This tag simply sets a value called [c]title[/c] on the context, which can be rendered in a templates. Here's an example:

    [code xml]
    <content libname="content.front" template="front.html">
        <title>Welcome!<title>
    </content>
    [/code]

    A reference to [c]title[/c] would appear somewhere in the template associated with the content. For example:

    [code moyatemplate]
    <html>
       <head>
           <title>${title}</title>
        </head>
        <body>
            {% render sections.body %}
        </body>
    </html>
    [/code]

<try>

</try>
<catch exception="*">
    <echo>The try block threw an exception</echo>
</catch>

http://moyaproject.com/wysihtml5.name: editor
http://moyaproject.com/wysihtml5.doc:
A rich text editor.

            The [c]buttons[/c] and [c]rbuttons[/c] attributes may be used to configure the row of buttons at the top of the editor. You can set them to a comma separated list of the following possible values:

            [definitions]
            [define bold]Bold [b]text[/b][/define]
            [define italic]Italic [i]text[/i][/define]
            [define underline]Underline [u]text[/u][/define]
            [define strike]Strikethrough [s]text[/s][/define]
            [define h1 - h7]Header level 1 through 7[/define]
            [define ol]Ordered List[/define]
            [define ul]Unordered List[/define]
            [define left]Left align[/define]
            [define center]Center align[/define]
            [define right]Right align[/define]
            [define justify]Justify text[/define]
            [define quote]Block quote[/define]
            [define link]Insert a link[/define]
            [define image]Insert an image[/define]
            [define view]Switch between rich text and markup view[/define]
            [/definitions]

            You can also add a bar symbol ([b]|[/b]) which will insert a divider between the buttons.

            The default for buttons is to have all text controls on the left, and the view button on the right.

name.doc: The name attribute of the textarea.

rbuttons.name: rbuttons
rbuttons.doc: A list of buttons on the right hand side.

Defines an argument to a macro.

The text of this tag should document the purpose of the argument.
tags.synopsis: define an argument to a macro

required.name: required
required.doc: Is this argument required?

check.name: check
check.doc: A boolean expression that the attribute must satisfy

tags.example:
<macro docname="average">
            <signature>
                <argument name="numbers" required="yes" check="len:numbers gt 0">
                    A list (or other sequence) of numbers
                </argument>
            </signature>
            <return value="sum:numbers / len:numbers" />
        </macro>

tags.name: ask
tags.doc:
Ask the user a yes / no question.

[alert WARNING]This tag should only be used in an interactive context, such as a [tag]command[/tag] tag.[/alert]
tags.example:
<ask dst="take_off">Would you like to take off?</ask>
        <echo if="take_off">Taking off!</echo>

tags.name: atomic
tags.doc:
Makes the enclosed block [i]atomic[/i].

An atomic block works much like [tag db]transaction[/tag], but uses the databases SAVEPOINT feature to better handle nested atomic blocks.
tags.synopsis: mark a block as being atomic
tags.example:
<!--- taken from Moya Social Links -->
        <db:atomic>
            <db:get model="#Link" let:id="link" dst="link" />
            <db:get model="#Vote" let:link="link" dst="vote" />
            <db:create if="not vote"
                model="#Vote" let:link="link" let:user=".user" let:score="score" dst="vote" />
            <let link.score="link.score - vote.score" vote.score="score" />
            <let link.score="link.score + vote.score" />
        </db:atomic>

tags.name: attempt
tags.doc:
Repeat a block of code if an exception is thrown. This is useful in situations where you are creating a database object
    with a random token, and you want to repeat the code if the random token happens to exist. The [c]wait[/c] attribute can set a timespan
    to wait between attempts, which may be appropriate for connecting to servers, for example.

    If an exception occurs, after [c]times[/c] attempts, then it will be thrown normally.

    [aside]Always set [c]times[/c] to a reasonable value. Programming errors could result in Moya getting stuck in a pointless loop.[/aside]
tags.synopsis: repeat a block until it is successful

wait.name: wait
wait.doc: Time to wait between syncs (default doesn't wait)

times.name: times
times.doc: Maximum number of times to repeat attempt block

tags.name: attribute
tags.doc: Defines an attribute in a [tag]tag[/tag], [tag]data-tag[/tag] or [tag]widget[/tag].
tags.synopsis: define an attribute in a custom tag

required.name: required
required.doc: Required

tags.example:
<datatag name="module">
            <doc>Define a top level admin module</doc>
            <signature>
                <attribute name="slug" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="title" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="description" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="content" type="elementref" required="no" />
            </signature>
        </datatag>

<bool dst="bool"/> <!-- False -->

        <bool dst="bool">no</bool> <!-- False -->
        <bool dst="bool" value="1"/> <!--True -->

tags.name: break
tags.doc: This tag will [i]break[/i] a loop such as [tag]while[/tag], [tag]for[/tag]. When Moya encounters this tag, it jumps to the statement after the loop.
tags.example:
<let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius', 'Aeryn']"/>
        <for src="crew" dst="character">
            <if test="character == 'Scorpius'">
                <echo>Taking off before Scorpius gets on board!</eco>
                <break>
            </if>
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </for>

tags.name: breakpoint
tags.doc: Stops the execute of Moya code and drops in to the debugger.
tags.example:
<!-- drop in to the debugger -->
        <breakpoint/>

        <for src="-100..100" dst="count">
            <!-- Conditional breakpoint with 'if' attribute -->
            <breakpoint if="count==0"/>
            <!-- This throws an exception when count is 0 -->
            <echo>${1/count}<echo>
        </for>

tags.name: cache-return
tags.doc:
Return a value from a cache, if it exists. Otherwise, execute the enclosed block.

This tag can be used to [i]memoize[/i] a [tag]macro[/tag] or other callable. Essentially, this means that if you call the macro a second time with the same parameters, it returns the previously calculated result. For macros that are slow to execute, this can result in significant speedups.

For example, the following code calculates the [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factorial]factorial[/url] of a number:


[code xml]
<moya xmlns="http://moyaproject.com"
    xmlns:let="http://moyaproject.com/let">

    <macro docname="fact">
        <signature>
            <argument name="n"/>
        </signature>
        <cache-return key="n">
            <echo>calculating ${n}!</echo>
            <let f="1"/>
            <while test="n">
                <let f="f*n" n="n-1"/>
            </while>
            <return value="f"/>
        </cache-return>
    </macro>

    <macro docname="main">
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
    </macro>

</moya>
[/code]

If you run the above code, you will get the following output:

[code]
$ moya run cachereturn.xml
calculating 7!
5040
5040
5040
[/code]

The first time the [c]fact[/c] macro is called, Moya displays "calculating 7!" in the terminal. The second and third time, the text is [i]not[/i] displayed because the result is retrieved from the cache -- without the need to execute the code within [tag]cache-return[/tag].

tags.name: case
tags.doc:
Defines a case in a [tag]switch[/tag] tag.

If a [c]value[/c] attribute is given, it will be used as the comparison values, otherwise the tag text will be used.
tags.synopsis: define a case in a switch

value.name: value

tags.name: case

tags.name: catch
tags.doc: Catches any [link moyacode#exceptions]exceptions[/link] from the previous block.
tags.synopsis: catch exceptions from the previous block
tags.example:
<try>
    <echo>${1/0}</echo>  <!-- will throw a math exception -->
</try>
<catch exception="math.divistion-error">
    <echo>The try block threw an exception</echo>
</catch>

<!-- A <try> block is only necessary if there are multiple statements you want to catch exceptions for -->
<echo>${1/0}<echo>
<catch exception="math.division-error">
    <echo>You can't divide by zero!</echo>
</catch>

A check select is an alternative to a multiple select ([tag forms]select[/tag]) which uses checkboxes rather than an input.

tags.name: command
tags.doc:
Defines a command accessible from the command line. To invoke a command enter its full app name after 'moya'. For example:

    [code]$ moya testapp#cmd.hello World
Hello, World!
    [/code]

    You can also get a list of available commands for an application, by supplying the app name followed by #. For example:

    [code]$ moya testapp#[/code]

    See [doc commands] for more information.

synopsis.name: synopsis
synopsis.doc: Command synopsis, displayed when you list commands

tags.example:
<command libname="cmd.hello" sypopsis="Greet someone on the commandline">
            <signature>
                <arg name="who" help="Who you want to greet">
            </signature>
            <echo>Hello, ${who}!</echo>
        </command>

tags.name: comments
tags.doc: Render comments on a page.

tags.name: commit
tags.doc:
Commit any pending transaction. This will [i]flush[/i] db operations to the database. If you have create new objects and you want to know their [i]primary key[/i] (id), you will need to commit them to the database.

Note, that if this tag is called from within a [tag db]transaction[/tag] tag, nothing will be committed until the end of the [tag db]transaction[/tag].

tags.name: content
tags.doc:
Begin a [link content]content[/link] definition.

Content is a high level description of a page.
tags.example:
<content libname="content.crew.manifest">
            <title>Crew Manifest</title>
            <section name="content">
                <for src="crew" dst="character">
                    <moya:crew character="character"/>
                </form>
            </section>
            <section name="footer">
                <markdown>Brought to you by **Moya**.</markdown>
            </section>
        </content>

tags.name: continue
tags.doc: When Moya encounters this tag in a loop, such as [tag]while[/tag] or [tag]for[/tag], it ignores the remaining code in the block and [i]continues[/i] to the next item in the loop.
tags.synopsis: skip remaining code in a loop
tags.example:
<let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius', 'Aeryn']"/>
        <for src="crew" dst="character">
            <if test="character == 'Scorpius'">
                <echo>Scorpius is not allowed on board!</eco>
                <continue/>
            </if>
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </for>

                let:first_name="first_name"

tags.name: datetime
tags.doc:
Create a Moya [i]datetime[/i] object.

Datetime objects have the following properties:

[definitions]
    [define year]The year (integer)[/define]
    [define month]The month (integer) (1 is January)[/define]
    [define day]The day (integer)[/define]
    [define hour]The hours in the time[/define]
    [define minute]The number of minutes in the time[/define]
    [define second]The number of seconds in the time[/define]
    [define microseconds]The number of microseconds in the time[/define]
    [define isoformat]The date/time in [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601]ISO 8601[/url] format[/define]
    [define next_day]The date/time + 24 hours[/define]
    [define previous_day]The date/time - 24 hours[/define]
    [define year_start]January 1st at the beginning of the year[/define]
    [define day_start]The beginning of the day (midnight)[/define]
    [define next_year]January 1st of the next year[/define]
    [define next_month]First day of the next month[/define]
    [define next_day]The start of the next day[/define]
    [define previous_day]The start of the previous day[/define]
    [define previous_year]Jan 1st of the previous year[/define]
    [define previous_monthy]First date of the previous month[/define]
    [define days_in_month]Number of days in the current month[/define]
    [define epoch]Number of seconds since Jan 1st 1970[/define]
    [define html5_datatime]Date/Time in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define html5_data]Date in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define html_time]Time in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define utc]Date/Time in UTC timezone[/define]
    [define local]DateTime in local timezone (references [c].tz[/c])[/define]
[/definitions]
tags.example:
<datetime year="1974" month="7" day="5" dst="birthday" />
        <echo>Your birthday is ${localize:birthday}</echo>

tags.name: datetime
tags.doc: Defines a [i]datetime[/i] field.
tags.synopsis: a field that stores a date and time

auto.name: auto
auto.doc: Set to current time when created

tags.example: <datetime name="last_login" label="Date of last login" null="yes" />

tags.name: debug
tags.doc:
Executes a block only if Moya is in debug mode. You can enable debug mode the setting 'debug' under the project section. This tag is equivalent to the following:

[code xml]
<if test=".debug">
    <echo>Moya is in debug mode. Relax.</echo>
</if>
[/code]

[alert]Be careful to not do anything inside this tag that your project may depend on. It will not execute in a production environment![/alert]

tags.name: dec
tags.doc: Decrement (subtract 1 from) a value.

tags.name: dedent
tags.doc: Removes common whitespace from the start of lines.
tags.synopsis: remove common whitespace from a string
tags.example:
<dedent dst="text">
            This text will have the initial whitespace removed
                This will start with only 4 spaces
            Back to column 0
        </dedent>

tags.name: default-case
tags.doc: Defines the [i]default[/i] case in a [tag]switch[/tag] tag.

tags.name: default-markup
tags.doc: Use default markup if a value is None or missing
tags.synopsis: use default markup for missing values

tags.name: defer
tags.doc: Defer to a given element, such as a [tag]macro[/tag]. [i]Deferring[/i] to a macro is similar to calling it, but no new [i]scope[/i] is created. This means that the macro has access to the same variables where defer was called.
tags.example:
<macro docname="board">
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </macro>

        <macro docname="main">
            <let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius']"/>
            <for src="crew" dst="character">
                <defer to="board"/>
            </for>
        </macro>

tags.name: delete
tags.doc: Delete an object from the database.

tags.name: delete-all
tags.doc: Delete every object from a table
tags.synopsis: delete all objects in a table

tags.name: delete-cookie
tags.doc: Delete a previously set cookie.

tags.name: dict
tags.doc: Create a [i]dictionary[/i] object. A dictionary maps [i]keys[/i] on to [i]values[/i]. The keys and values are defined in the enclosing block, or via the [i]let map[/i].

default.name: default
default.doc: Default object to return if the key isn't in the dict

sequence.name: sequence
sequence.doc: Optional sequence of key / value pairs to initialize the dict

tags.example:
<dict dst="species">
            <str dst="Bibo">Hobbit</dst>
            <str dst="Gandalph">Wizard</dst>
        </dict>
        <!-- Alternatively -->
        <dict dst="species" let:Bilbo="Hobbit" let:Gandalph="Wizard" />
        <echo>Bilbo is a ${species['Bilbo']}</echo>

tags.name: doc
tags.doc: Write documentation for a widget or custom tag.
tags.example:
<widget name="post" template="post.html">
            <doc>Renders a single post</doc>
            <!-- widget code -->
        </widget>

tags.name: done
tags.doc: Exists the current callable immediately with no return value. Note, this is not equivalent to [tag]return[/tag] which returns [c]None[/c].
tags.synopsis: return from a macro or callable without any data

tags.name: echo
tags.doc: Write text to the console. This is typically used in commands or for debugging. Bear in mind that in a production environment there is no console.

header.name: header
header.doc: A list of headers for the table (if given)

obj.name: obj
obj.doc: If given, then the value of this expression will be written to the console

table.name: table
table.doc: A table to display. If given this value should be a list of lists.

tags.name: editor
tags.doc:
A rich text editor.

            The [c]buttons[/c] and [c]rbuttons[/c] attributes may be used to configure the row of buttons at the top of the editor. You can set them to a comma separated list of the following possible values:

            [definitions]
            [define bold]Bold [b]text[/b][/define]
            [define italic]Italic [i]text[/i][/define]
            [define underline]Underline [u]text[/u][/define]
            [define strike]Strikethrough [s]text[/s][/define]
            [define h1 - h7]Header level 1 through 7[/define]
            [define ol]Ordered List[/define]
            [define ul]Unordered List[/define]
            [define left]Left align[/define]
            [define center]Center align[/define]
            [define right]Right align[/define]
            [define justify]Justify text[/define]
            [define quote]Block quote[/define]
            [define link]Insert a link[/define]
            [define image]Insert an image[/define]
            [define view]Switch between rich text and markup view[/define]
            [/definitions]

            You can also add a bar symbol ([b]|[/b]) which will insert a divider between the buttons.

            The default for buttons is to have all text controls on the left, and the view button on the right.

name.name: name
name.doc: The name attribute of the textarea.

rbuttons.name: rbuttons
rbuttons.doc: A list of buttons on the right hand side.

tags.name: elif
tags.doc: Executes the enclosed block if a previous [tag]if[/tag] (or [tag]elif[/tag]) statement is false, and another condition is true.
tags.example:
<if test="hobbits == 0">
    <echo>There are no hobbits</echo>
</if>
<elif test="hobbits == 1">
    <echo>There is one hobbit</echo>
</elif>
<else>
    <echo>There are many hobbits</echo>
</else>

tags.name: else
tags.doc: Execute the enclosed block if a previous [tag]if[/tag] statement is false.
tags.synopsis: execute a block if the previous <if> statement is false
tags.example:
<if test="coffee==0">
    <echo>Get more coffee</echo>
</if>
<else>
    <echo>Have a cup of coffee</echo>
</else>

tags.name: email
tags.doc: Define an email.

tags.name: enum
tags.doc:
Define and [i]enumeration[/i] object. An enumeration is a collection of text identifiers with an integer value. This tag should contain [tag]value[/tag] tags that define the values.

    It is generally preferably to use an enumeration over hard-coded numbers; it makes code easier to read and maintain.

start.name: start
start.doc: Starting ID if not specified in <enumvalue>

tags.example:
<enum libname="enum.jsonrpc.errors">
            <value id="1" label="not_logged_in" description="You must be logged in to do that" />
            <value label="invalid_score" description="Score must be -1, 0 or +1"/>
            <value label="unknown_link" description="Link object was not found"/>
        </enum>

tags.name: error
tags.doc: Set an error message on either a field or the entire form.
tags.synopsis: add an error message to a form
tags.example:
<forms:error src="form" if=".user">
            You must be logged in to do that!
        </forms:error>

tags.name: error
tags.doc: Return an rpc error response.

tags.name: error
tags.doc: Renders an error message.

tags.name: exit
tags.doc: Exit the current command. When Moya sees this tag it stops running the current command and returns an exit code. It will also write any enclosed text to the console.

tags.name: extend
tags.doc: Extend a sequence with values from another sequence.
tags.synopsis: add values from one sequence to another

tags.name: fail
tags.doc:
Used in a [tag forms]validate-feld[/tag], this tag marks a field as having failed validation, and sets an error message.

Note that this tag acts like a [tag]return[/tag].
tags.synopsis: set a fail in a form validation
tags.example:
<validate-field field="price">
            <fail if="value lte 0>
                Price must be greater than 0.00.
            </fail>
        </validate-field>

tags.name: fail
tags.doc: Note a failed test

tags.name: false
tags.doc: Creates a boolean with a value of False.

tags.name: feed
tags.doc:
Create a [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS]RSS[/url] Feed object.

You can add items to a feed with [tag]add-feed-item[/tag].
tags.example:
<view libname="view.feed">
            <!-- create feed object -->
            <get-fq-url name="list" dst="blog_url" />
            <feed title="${.app.settings.title or 'blog'}"
                description="${.app.settings.description or 'blog feed'}"
                link="${blog_url}" dst="feed"/>

            <db:query model="#Post" dst="posts" orderby="-published_date"
                filter="#Post.published==True" maxresults="25"/>

            <!-- add items -->
            <for src="posts" dst="post">
                <get-fq-url name="showpost" let:slug="post.slug" dst="post_url"/>
                <process-markup src="post.content" type="${.app.settings.default_markup}" dst="description"/>
                <add-feed-item src="feed"
                    title="post.title" link="post_url" description="description"
                    pub_date="post.published_date"/>
            </for>

            <!-- serve feed XML -->
            <serve-xml content_type="application/rss+xml" obj="feed"/>
        </view>

tags.name: field
tags.doc: This tag adds a field to the form object, but defers the rendering to enclosed content.
tags.synopsis: add a custom field to a form

required.name: required
required.doc: Is a value required for this field?

help.name: help
help.doc: Help text

process.name: process
process.doc: Function to process src in to a string

adapt.name: adapt
adapt.doc: Function to adapt field before applying

tags.name: filter
tags.doc:
Define a [i]filter[/i], which may be used in expressions.

Here's an example of a filter:

[code xml]
<filter name="repeat">
    <return-str>${str:value * count}</return-str>
</filter>
[/code]

And here is how you might use it in an expression:

[code xml]
<echo>${"beetlejuice "|repeat(count=3)}</echo>
[/code]

tags.name: filter-seq
tags.doc: Filter members of a collection which don't pass a condition.
tags.example:
<dict dst="crew">
            <dict let:name="john" let:species="human" />
            <dict let:name="rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />
        </dict>
        <filter-seq src="items:crew dst="crew" test="species !- 'hyneria'"/>
        <!-- [{'name': 'john', 'species':'human'}, {'name':'aeryn', 'species':'peacemaker'}] -->

tags.name: find-element

tags.name: find-elements

tags.name: handle
tags.doc:
Handles a [i]signal[/i]. A signal is a way of broadcasting to other parts of the project that a particular event has occurred.

See [doc signals] for more information.

sender.doc: Only handle the signal(s) if sent from this element.

tags.example:
<!-- Moya fires a number of signals itself, for various system events -->
        <handle signal="sys.startup">
            <log>This code executes on startup, prior to any requests</log>
        </handle>
        <!-- Handle a custom signal -->
        <handle signal="mordor.arrived">
            <log>${hobbit} has arrived in Mordor!</log>
        </handle>
